thread.title: Harrison Ford flies over airliner, could have caused serious mishap. Watch video
thread.title_full: Harrison Ford flies over airliner, could have caused serious mishap. Watch video

title: Harrison Ford flies over airliner, could have caused serious mishap. Watch video
text:
Harrison Ford flies over airliner, could have caused serious mishap. Watch video Harrison Ford flies over airliner, could have caused serious mishap. Watch video An American Airlines 737 is taxiing slowly. Then Harrison Ford's yellow, single-engine Aviat Husky suddenly zooms in from the right of the frame, flying low over the airliner. By: AP | Updated:  22 pm The 45 seconds of soundless video show how Harrison Ford suddenly and mistakenly flying low over an airliner with 110 people aboard at a Southern California airport. 
Video released Tuesday shows a plane piloted by Harrison Ford suddenly and mistakenly flying low over an airliner with 110 people aboard at a Southern California airport. 
The 45 seconds of soundless video show the 74-year-old “Star Wars” and “Indiana Jones” star’s potentially serious mishap at John Wayne Airport in Orange County. 
In it, an American Airlines 737 is taxiing slowly. Then Ford’s yellow, single-engine Aviat Husky suddenly zooms in from the right of the frame, flying low over the airliner and casting its shadow down the middle of the bigger plane before landing on the taxiway. 
Ford was supposed to have landed on a runway that runs parallel to the taxiway. “Was that airliner meant to be underneath me?” Ford asks in previously released sound from the air traffic control tower. But for the airliner, the taxiway and runway are both wide-open and apparently unmistakable. 
  video then shows the same landing from the back, giving more time to the approach of Ford’s plane, but the flyover itself is barely visible. 
Watch | Video Shows Harrison Ford Wrongly Fly Over Plane 

No reason has been given for why Ford made the mistake, and his publicist has not replied to requests for comment. The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating the incident. 
American Airlines Flight 1456, with 110 passengers and six crew members aboard, departed safely for Dallas a few minutes later. Ford collects vintage planes and has a long and good record as an aviator. 
But he has had several close-calls and a serious accident in March 2015 when he was injured in his World War II-era trainer as it crashed on a Los Angeles golf course. Tags:
